div.span: Tulsa Public Schools is on a journey to be the destination for excellence in teaching and learning, and we invite you to join us! We have positions available throughout the district: from our classrooms, to our transportation hubs, to our district office. If you are ready to make a difference for teachers, children, and families, we have a place for you at Tulsa Public Schools!

li.a: Tulsa MET High & Jr. High School

div.p: The coronavirus situation is changing rapidly by the hour, and we are working from the most current information available to us and with consultation from health and safety experts. We are sharing our updated information on our website. You can also sign-up for text message alerts from Tulsa Public Schools by texting “YES” to 67587.

li.a: Tulsa Public Schools COVID-19 Update: Monday, April 13
Tulsa Public Schools COVID-19 Update: Thursday, April 9
Tulsa Public Schools COVID-19 Update: Friday, April 3
Tulsa Public Schools COVID-19 Update: Monday, March 23
Tulsa Public Schools Covid-19 Update: Friday, March 20

Tulsa Public Schools Covid-19 Update: Saturday, March 14
Tulsa Public Schools COVID-19 Update: Thursday, March 12

h2.a: Tulsa Public Schools COVID-19 Update: Monday, April 13

div.p: Starting Monday, April 13, Tulsa Public Schools will provide educational television programming on the district’s TPS20 Cox channel and RSU-TV to support distance learning for students in grades pre-kindergarten through 8th. This programming covers educational topics ranging from phonics lessons, read-alouds in English and Spanish, math lessons, wellness/fitness programs, STEM education, and fine arts. The program offerings are designed to help supplement content areas that students normally have access to in their classrooms.

“We are working with community partners and our own classroom teachers to create programs to help keep students engaged and learning,” said Superintendent Deborah A. Gist. “It has been exciting to see our Tulsa-area companies and partners stepping in to support families, and I am confident our students and their families are going to benefit from this new way of learning.”

Tulsa Public Schools will use the district’s Cox cable access channel, TPS20, to provide content for pre-kindergarten through 8th, including daily read-alouds and math for each elementary grade level. These learning programs will air Monday through Friday from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. on channel 20.1 through May 15. The district will also air weekly segments for social emotional learning, physical education, and art and music.

In partnership with RSU-TV, learning programs will air live every Monday and Wednesday from 9 a.m. to 12 p.m. on channel 35.1 through May 15. Classes will address core subject areas such as the arts, STEM, reading, physical education, as well as social emotional learning.

Tulsa Public Schools is committed to providing the resources families need offline and online for at-home learning activities that focus on reading, writing, and problem-solving. To learn more, visit www.tulsaschools.org/distancelearning.

h2.a: Tulsa Public Schools COVID-19 Update: Thursday, April 9

div.p: As we navigate through our first week of distance learning, we are continuing to focus on building strong student-teacher relationships. We also want to provide students with meaningful content to support their learning through the end of the school year.

We understand the barriers you may be facing during this difficult time, and we want you to know that we do not expect you to home-school your student. In other words, you are not expected to recreate school at home. That would be impossible even in the best of times!

We do want to support you to continue their learning as best as you can. We are committed to providing the resources you need offline and online for at-home learning activities that focus on reading, writing, and problem-solving. That is why we have made a few changes to ensure more information and resources about distance learning are available on our website at www.tulsaschools.org/distancelearning.

On our website, you can find learning resources divided by grade level. Each section includes student learning schedules, learning packets, television programming, and links to resources. You can find those resources here:

Starting Friday, April 10, families can pick up printed learning packets at all Tulsa Public Schools grab-and-go meal sites for students who are not working online. If you are working online, you can still pick up packets if you would like.

We will distribute a total of three learning packets between now and the end of the school year. Families can pick up the first at-home learning packet between April 10 and April 17, which will include one week of content.
Additional packets will be available for pickup April 17 through May 1 and May 1 through May 15. These packets will have two weeks of at-home learning content.

The learning packets will not need to be returned and might look different than the home assignments your student’s teacher provides. You can find meal site locations and hours at www.tulsaschools.org/mealsites. Please note, students participating in online learning with their teacher do not need to complete these printed learning packets.

Please also do not hesitate to contact your child’s school leader with any questions or suggestions that you might have. You can find more information, resources, and updates at www.tulsaschools.org/distancelearning. We’ll also continue to add to our frequently asked questions based on the feedback we hear from you.

h2.a: Tulsa Public Schools COVID-19 Update: Friday, April 3

div.p: Distance learning at Tulsa Public Schools will begin on Monday, April 6. Our school leaders and teachers have missed your children, and we are looking forward to resuming teaching and learning next week! This letter is lengthy because it includes a lot of important information for families to support our transition to distance learning. Please try to find a moment in your busy day to read through this information - I think you will find it useful.

While distance learning will look and feel different, we are continuing to focus on building strong student-teacher relationships and providing students with meaningful content that sustains learning through the end of the school year. Additionally, we will share online and offline resources for at-home learning activities that focus on reading, writing, and problem-solving.

I know that you likely have many questions about what the rest of the school year will look like, and I am including answers to some frequently asked questions below. You can find more information, resources, and updates at www.tulsaschools.org/distancelearning. We’ll also continue to add to our frequently asked questions based on the feedback we hear from you.

p.b: What will the first week of distance learning look like?

div.p: During the first week of distance learning, teachers will call and “meet” with students, introduce the learning platforms, set up rituals and routines for the distance learning process, and engage in learning activities with students. Teachers and school team members will also connect with families to communicate schedules for online learning as well as at-home learning activities. We expect the first week may be a little bumpy as we all learn to "do school" together differently. If you do not receive a call, please reach out to your school leader directly to ensure that we have an updated phone number for you.

p.b: What can I expect during distance learning through the rest of the school year?

div.p: Your child will learn through a combination of recorded videos, television programming, and real-time video calls using Zoom. Students will use the web-based program Canvas to find lessons and complete assignments. Students will also have the opportunity to complete paper-based assignments. You can find links and resources related to distance learning at www.tulsaschools.org/distancelearning.

p.b: Will assignments during distance learning be graded?

div.p: No. Teachers will provide feedback on student work, but students will not receive official grades on assignments. Individual assignments will not be recorded in Powerschool.

p.b: Will my student receive a grade at the end of the year?

div.p: Student report cards for quarter three (the period ending March 12) will be available in late April. You will be able to access quarter three report cards through the PowerSchool app or by scheduling to pick up a printed copy from your child’s school. We will be sharing additional information about student grades in the next week.

p.b: Will high school students earn credit for their spring semester courses?

div.p: All high school students with a passing grade in a credit-bearing course at the end of the year will receive course credit. Teachers and counselors will work with students over the coming weeks to ensure that students who were in danger of failing on March 12 have the opportunity to improve their current course grade through assignments.

p.b: What will the learning day look like?

div.p: Classes provided through video, television, and video calls will take approximately 30-45 minutes each. Students will have additional assignments to work on during the day. Students are not expected to be sitting in front of a computer or television for a specific amount of time - distance learning is designed to be flexible. Students will also have regular check-ins with their teachers: daily for elementary grades and weekly for secondary grades. Your child’s teacher will contact you to share more information about learning schedules.

p.b: How can I prepare for distance learning?

div.p: There are some steps you can take to make sure that your child is ready to resume learning next week:

● Pick-up a laptop from your child’s school. School leaders are scheduling opportunities for families to borrow one device for each child enrolled at Tulsa Public Schools. If you have not heard from your child’s school, please contact your school leader directly.

● Update your contact information. Teachers will use phone, email, and postal mail to contact your students. Please make sure that we have an accurate address, phone number, and e-mail on file for you. Contact updatemyinfo@tulsaschools.org to update your information. Please include the name of your school in the subject line.
● Bookmark our website. The Tulsa Public Schools website at www.tulsaschools.org is being updated frequently with news, information, and resources for families.

p.b: I do not have internet services at home. How can my child participate in distance learning?

div.p: We will make printed materials available at all Tulsa Public Schools grab-and-go meal sites. You can find site locations and hours at www.tulsaschools.org/mealsites. Additionally, there are companies and services that provide low-cost home internet or wireless internet free of charge. You can find more information about those options and about our “mobile hotspot” buses at www.tulsaschools.org/internet.

p.b: What websites, programs, or applications will students be using?

div.p: We will be posting information and links related to distance learning on our website at www.tulsaschools.org/distancelearning. The primary programs that students and teachers will use are:
● Canvas: www.tulsaschools.org/canvas
● Zoom: www.zoom.us/signin
● Google Classroom: www.classroom.google.com
● District website: www.tulsaschools.org
Your child’s school will contact you to provide log-in information for these sites.

We are continuing to update our website frequently, so please bookmark www.tulsaschools.org and visit it regularly. Please also do not hesitate to contact your child’s school leaders with any questions or suggestions that you might have as we work together to keep Tulsa children engaged and learning through the end of the school year.

h2.a: Tulsa Public Schools COVID-19 Update: Monday, March 23

div.p: This afternoon, State Superintendent Joy Hofmeister shared her intention to recommend to the Oklahoma State Board of Education that our state implement a continuous learning plan without reopening school buildings. This means that, if approved by the state board, instruction of students would resume remotely on April 6 and that our school buildings will NOT reopen this year.

We anticipate that the Oklahoma State Board of Education will consider and take action on this recommendation on Wednesday, March 25. The Oklahoma State Department of Education and Superintendent Hofmeister have already suspendedstate testing for the 2019–2020 school year and willensure that student absences related to COVID-19 will not impact a child’s future opportunities.

We care about every single one of you – our students, our team, our families. We love you, and we want you to be safe and healthy. We recognize the enormity of Superintendent Hofmeister’s recommendation, and we have been working urgently over the last week to put plans in place to support students and families through a longer closure. While we are still working through a number of issues, we want Tulsa families to know that, in the very likely event of a longer closure:

ul.li: We will continue to provide breakfast and lunch meals to our students; and
Our school leaders and teachers will have plans in place to support student learning and engagement after April 6.

div.p: This is an unprecedented situation, and it is changing rapidly. We know that our team, students, and families have many questions. In particular, we know that our high school juniors and seniors are making post-secondary plans and need to understand what will happen next. Know that we hear your concerns and questions and that the district and your school will stay in close contact with you to address them. We are also working on a set of frequently asked questions for our high school juniors and seniors. Please don’t hesitate to raise your concerns directly to your school’s leadership team as well.

We know that the uncertainty of this situation - especially when combined with this unprecedented experience - can be difficult and scary for all of us. Our commitment to you is to continue to share what we know for certain as soon as we know it, to answer your questions and address your concerns to the best of our ability, and to do all that we can to support everyone in our city as we make our way through this challenging time.

For more information and updates about our response to COVID-19, at-home engagement and enrichment activities for students, and meal services for children, visit our website at www.tulsaschools.org. We are updating our website multiple times a day to make sure you have the most up to date information, so please bookmark it and check back often.

h2.a: Tulsa Public Schools Covid-19 Update: Friday, March 20

div.p: While schools remain closed as a preventive measure against the spread of COVID-19, Tulsa Public Schools will provide all children ages 18 and under with nutritious meals free of charge. The district will provide “Grab-and-Go” breakfast and lunch meals at approximately 40 sites and deliver “Mobile Meals” to approximately 170 bus sites throughout the city starting on Monday, March 23. Meal services will be provided from Monday, March 23 until Friday, April 3. In the event of a longer closure, the district will continue to provide meals to Tulsa children. Families can find meal-sites and service times at www.tulsaschools.org/mealsites.

h2.a: Tulsa Public Schools COVID-19 Update: Monday, March 16

div.p: We love our students and team and are deeply dedicated to keeping everyone safe and well. Team Tulsa continues to work with health and safety experts to stay updated on the status and spread of coronavirus/COVID-19.
While this situation is changing by the hour, our most current information is as follows:

ul.li: To slow the spread COVID-19 in our community, all schools in our district will be closed through Friday, April 3. At this time, students will return to classes no earlier than Monday, April 6. Families should anticipate that there may be an even longer closure.
District office buildings will be open Monday, March 16 and Tuesday, March 17. Beginning on Wednesday, March 18, district buildings will be closed until Friday, April 3.

Employees should anticipate that there may be an even longer closure. In the next three days, we will share information with our employees about their schedules through Friday, April 3. All staff will continue to be paid through Friday, April 3.

div.p: We will continue to share information and updates through email, text message, and on our website. You can also sign-up for text message alerts from Tulsa Public Schools by texting “YES” to 67587.

h2.a: Tulsa Public Schools Covid-19 Update: Saturday, March 14

div.p: Conditions around COVID-19 are changing by the hour, and we are working to make the best decisions we can to keep our team and students safe.

On Monday, March 16 at 5 p.m., our Board of Education will hold an emergency meeting where we will discuss Superintendent Gist's recommendation and plans for extending spring break by one week or more. This meeting is open to the public and will take place in the Selman Room at the Education Service Center. However, we know that one important way to prevent the spread of COVID-19 is through social distancing, so we encourage you to consider joining the meeting virtually through our video livestream.

h2.a: Tulsa Public Schools COVID-19 Update: Thursday, March 12

div.p: As families prepare for the spring break, we want to provide important additional information about our out-of-state travel guidance to our students, parents, and employees.

The coronavirus situation is changing rapidly by the hour. If you have plans to travel out-of-state during spring break, please be aware that there is a very real possibility that you may need to self-quarantine for 14 days upon your return. This potential of a 14-day self-quarantine would apply to all students and employees of Tulsa Public Schools. You can find more information about self-quarantine protocols on the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention website at www.cdc.gov.

h2.a: FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS
Questions from Parents and Families

li.a: HOW WILL TULSA PUBLIC SCHOOLS SHARE UPDATES WITH FAMILIES?
How long will Tulsa Public School Buildings be closed?
Will Tulsa Public Schools feed students during the school closure?
How does Tulsa Public Schools keep our buses clean?
What resources are available for mental health supports during the COVID-19 outbreak?
Can you elaborate on what you mean by distance learning? It sounds more like a list of links rather than a structured virtual learning plan.
Will there be paper packets for kids without internet access? Will there be paper packets for all kids such as their usual class work/homework?
Are you collaborating with districts in other states that are implementing distance learning?
Will there be a need for community help on delivering meals to those who most need it?
Will my kid still be able to move on? Will my kid be able to graduate? Will they force us to make up this time with summer school?
Will my kids still have to take state tests? What about AP tests? We’re counting on those to help alleviate some college courses.
Will we have to make up time at the end of the year? We already have vacation, swim lessons, camps, etc planned based on the original calendar.
What happens to my child’s ESS services in a distance learning model?
What happens to my child’s related services (speech, OT, PT, one-to-one para etc) in a distance learning model?
How will distance learning impact IEP timelines?
How will distance learning impact evaluation timelines?
What can I do at home to help my student with a disability in a distance learning model?

h2.a: HOW WILL TULSA PUBLIC SCHOOLS SHARE UPDATES WITH FAMILIES?

div.p: Updates will be shared with families via:

ul.li: Local television stations, newspaper, radio stations
Message on district phone line 918-746-6800
Text messages will be sent via SchoolMessenger from 675-87 number.

div.p: Starting this school year, we began using SchoolMessenger to keep our team and families updated on district news by both phone and text message. Make sure your contact information is up to date by emailing your name, your student's name and school name, your email address and the best number to reach you to enroll@tulsaschools.org or call 918-746-7500. Then, text "Yes" to 67587 to stay in the loop!

h2.a: How long will Tulsa Public School Buildings be closed?

div.p: The Oklahoma State Board of Education voted to approve State Superintendent Joy Hofmeister’s recommendation to implement a continuous learning plan without reopening school buildings. This means that while instruction of students resumed remotely on April 6, our school buildings will NOT reopen this school year.

Even as we face this unprecedented challenge, know that your child’s learning WILL continue this school year. Teaching and learning will look different over the next six weeks, but our teachers and school leaders will do all that they can to help students stay on track academically.
In the interim, know that:

ul.li: We will continue to provide breakfast and lunch meals to our students free of charge - you can find locations and times at www.tulsaschools.org/mealsites; and
We are providing activities and resources for at-home student engagement at www.tulsaschools.org/distancelearning, and printed materials are available at meal sites.
We will continue to provide updates and information for the class of 2020 at www.tulsaschools.org/seniors.

div.p: We will also continue to share information, updates, and resources on our website at www.tulsaschools.org.

h2.a: Will Tulsa Public Schools feed students during the school closure?

div.p: We will feed Tulsa Public School students and the students of our partner schools by providing “grab and go” meals at sites throughout the city.
Grab-and-Go meal service will be available on weekdays.
Service Schedule: 11 a.m. – 1 p.m. with curbside meal pick-up

p.br:
Monday-Thursday: lunch and breakfast for the following day
Friday: lunch and breakfast for the following Monday

div.p: Tulsa Public Schools buses will park at approximately 170 stops throughout the city and provide to-go meals to all children ages 18 and under. Buses will park for approximately five minutes or until the last meal is served.
Service Schedule: 11 a.m. – 1 p.m. on weekdays

Meals provided: Monday-Thursday: lunch and breakfast for the following day
Friday: lunch and breakfast for the following Monday

br.a: Haz aquí para obtener más información.

h2.a: How does Tulsa Public Schools keep our buses clean?

div.p: We take this and any health issue very seriously and have practices in place to keep our buses clean. We are regularly disinfecting school buses with the recommended products that are safe for staff and are sensitive to our employee’s allergies.

h2.a: What resources are available for mental health supports during the COVID-19 outbreak?

div.p: The Tulsa Health Department has a helpline for Tulsans dealing with disaster-related emotional distress at 1-800-985-5990. We have also compiled a list of mental health resources that may be helpful for our families and employees.
Our Employee Assistance Program offers support, advice, and/or guidance to help you face the challenges that come your way.
Eligible employees and their family members are entitled to up to five confidential sessions with a counselor, financial planner, or attorney each calendar year.
For more information, visit Employee Assistance Program.

h2.a: Can you elaborate on what you mean by distance learning? It sounds more like a list of links rather than a structured virtual learning plan.

div.p: The Oklahoma State Board of Education voted to approve State Superintendent Joy Hofmeister’s recommendation to implement a continuous learning plan without reopening school buildings. This means that while instruction of students resumed remotely on April 6, our school buildings will NOT reopen this school year.

Even as we face this unprecedented challenge, know that your child’s learning WILL continue this school year. Teaching and learning will look different over the next six weeks, but our teachers and school leaders will do all that they can to help students stay on track academically.

We know that not all of our families have access to internet services and computers. We are working urgently with school leaders and their teams to understand what support and tools our families and teachers need in order to engage in remote learning. It is important to know that distance learning does not require that families have devices at home. While technology is an incredibly helpful tool, we are working to accommodate the varied needs of the learners we serve.

h2.a: Will there be paper packets for kids without internet access? Will there be paper packets for all kids such as their usual class work/homework?

div.p: Students and families will be able to access instructional materials and resources through the use of hard copy textbooks, work packets, and in online/digital format where applicable. Information, learning materials, and resources will be added to tulsaschools.org/distancelearning.

We are compiling information for families on what resources are available for households who need internet access. As the situation progresses rapidly across the state and our nation, many technology and internet service providers such as Cox and AT&T are providing additional support in response to this unprecedented situation. Our goal is to help our families know about these opportunities. More information can be found on tulsaschools.org/internet.

We know that not all of our families have access to internet services and computers. We are working urgently with school leaders and their teams to understand what support and tools our families and teachers need in order to engage in distance learning. It is important to know that distance learning does not require that families have devices at home. While technology is an incredibly helpful tool, we are also working to accommodate the varied needs of the learners we serve.

h2.a: Are you collaborating with districts in other states that are implementing distance learning?

div.p: Yes! We are working with districts in Texas, Kansas, and more to learn how we can best serve our students. We will also continue to collaborate with Tulsa Classroom Teachers Association, our school leaders, and our teachers to provide students with quality instructional opportunities.

h2.a: Will there be a need for community help on delivering meals to those who most need it?

div.p: We are SO grateful for members of our team who have stepped up to help during this time! Right now, we do not need additional help but THANK YOU to everyone who has asked to help Team Tulsa!

Tulsa Public Schools is providing all children ages 18 and under with nutritious meals free of charge. The district is providing “Grab-and-Go” breakfast and lunch meals at approximately 40 sites and deliver “Mobile Meals” to approximately 170 bus sites throughout the city.

br.a: Haz aquí para obtener más información.

div.p: Providing free, nutritious, reliable meals for our students is one of Tulsa Public School’s most important services. We are uniquely equipped to provide this service because we have systems for large-scale meal preparation and distribution and funding from the government.
We are partnering with Hunger-Free Oklahoma, the Food Bank and the United Way to make this program possible and increase the number of students and families we can support during the closure.

h2.a: Will my kid still be able to move on? Will my kid be able to graduate? Will they force us to make up this time with summer school?

div.p: Even as we face this unprecedented challenge, know that your child’s learning WILL continue this school year. Teaching and learning will look different over the next six weeks, but our teachers and school leaders will do all that they can to help students stay on track academically.

While it is possible that we may be able to have graduation ceremonies this summer, our high school graduations will likely not be traditional ceremonies. However, our high school teachers and school leaders are committed to making sure that each senior earns their diploma and is able to celebrate that accomplishment.

We know that not all of our families have access to internet services and computers. We are working urgently with school leaders and their teams to understand what support and tools our families and teachers need in order to engage in remote learning. It is important to know that remote learning does not require that families have devices at home. While technology is an incredibly helpful tool, we are also working to accommodate the varied needs of the learners we serve.

h2.a: Will my kids still have to take state tests? What about AP tests? We’re counting on those to help alleviate some college courses.

div.p: We are working with the Oklahoma State Department of Education regarding concerns around attendance, chronic absenteeism, course credits, and participation in state assessments.

We are prioritizing this because while our students deserve the opportunity to participate in college and career assessments, it is more important to prioritize the safety and well-being of students and Team Tulsa members. The Oklahoma State Department of Education is already working on scheduling a fall testing window for the SAT assessment for our current 11th graders.

AP exams will be given online. The exams will be 45 minutes, and they will consist of free response questions only. The exams will cover the material that should have been taught by early March. Students can take the exam using any Internet enabled device including a phone. Please check the College Board website for further details. We recommend all AP students explore the resources on the College Board website including YouTube live videos, released exams, and other things to help you prepare to be successful on your AP exam.

h2.a: Will we have to make up time at the end of the year? We already have vacation, swim lessons, camps, etc planned based on the original calendar.

div.p: We are working with the Oklahoma State Department of Education regarding concerns around attendance, chronic absenteeism, course credits, and participation in state assessments.

We are prioritizing this because while our students deserve the opportunity to participate in college and career assessments, it is more important to prioritize the safety and well-being of students and Team Tulsa members. The Oklahoma State Department of Education is already working on scheduling a fall testing window for the SAT assessment for our current 11th graders.

h2.a: What happens to my child’s ESS services in a distance learning model?

div.p: Families should expect communication from their student’s teacher(s) to determine the level of support needed during this time. Special Education teachers are expected to touch base with their students a minimum of 2 times per week.

ul.li: For students who receive instruction in the general education setting, the general education curriculum will be provided by the general education teacher. Support will be provided by the special education teacher to apply the most appropriate accommodations/modifications to address the needs of the student individually. Depending on technology access within the home, teachers will provide student work via phone conferencing, Zoom calls or through specially designed instruction that can be utilized at home.

For students who receive services within a self-contained setting, your special education teacher will be providing specially designed instruction that will respond to your student’s unique needs. Please work with your special education teacher on the best way to deliver services to your student. Depending on technology access within the home, teachers will provide student work via phone conferencing, Zoom calls or through specially designed instruction that can be utilized at home.

h2.a: What happens to my child’s related services (speech, OT, PT, one-to-one para etc) in a distance learning model?

div.p: Related services will continue to be provided during this time; however, they will not look the same as they did before. The related service provider(s) who work with your student during the school day will also be contacting you to arrange an acceptable method to deliver services and support student needs. Services may include tele-therapy for any related service or written instructions (i.e., exercises to maintain range of motion or activities to do at home to maintain fine motor abilities). One-to-One para supports will not be provided within student homes during this time.

h2.a: How will distance learning impact IEP timelines?

div.p: IEP annual due dates may not be adjusted and continue to be required to be reviewed at least annually. The OSDE cannot waive these federal requirements for IEPs. If your student’s IEP is due, your student’s special education teacher will be reaching out to you to arrange an acceptable way to conduct the meeting via phone conference or Zoom meeting. Please see guidance provided to parents prepared by the Oklahoma Parents Center.

h2.a: How will distance learning impact evaluation timelines?

div.p: Timelines for Initial Evaluations and Re-Evaluations will not change. Initial evaluations will continue to need to be completed within 45 school days and Re-Evaluations will require IEP Teams to consider continued eligibility every three years. Unfortunately, some of these evaluations will require direct assessment provided by our evaluators (i.e., School Psychologist, School Psychometrist, Speech-Language Pathologists, etc.) and due to the current safety concerns, this will not be an option. We have provided guidance to our schools as to how to handle these circumstances and they will be in contact with you to explain options the team may consider.

h2.a: What can I do at home to help my student with a disability in a distance learning model?

div.p: Transition and change can be very difficult for students with disabilities. Providing structure within your day can help your child transition back to school more readily in the Fall.

ul.li: Create a visual schedule so that children can mark things off once they are complete.
Read their favorite books or have them read to you.
Make chore charts that provide tasks around the house.
Teach them how to prepare simple snacks or just organize the pantry!
Be sure to include some “down-time” for fun breaks doing the things your child loves the most.
For tips on how to talk with your child about COVID19, see this resource: https://childmind.org/article/talking-to-kids-about-the-coronavirus/

h2.a: Questions from Employees

li.a: Will support staff be paid during the closure?
Will teachers be paid during the closure?
How will I know when/whether I am supposed to come to work?
What resources are available for mental health supports during the COVID-19 outbreak?
Will teachers be allowed to work in classrooms for a few days before the students return? If we have to close the rest of the year, will teachers be able to close their rooms?

h2.a: Will support staff be paid during the closure?

div.p: On March 23, 2020, the Tulsa Public School Board adopted a new board policy stating that all regular employees of Tulsa Public Schools, including teachers, administrators and support employees, shall be entitled to pay at their full contract rate for any work time lost when school buildings are closed and they are unable to work because of an epidemic.

h2.a: Will teachers be paid during the closure?

div.p: On March 23, 2020, the Tulsa Public School Board adopted a new board policy stating that all regular employees of Tulsa Public Schools, including teachers, administrators and support employees, shall be entitled to pay at their full contract rate for any work time lost when school buildings is closed and they are unable to work because of an epidemic.

h2.a: How will I know when/whether I am supposed to come to work?

p.b: District buildings will NOT reopen this school year.

div.p: Employees should have received any necessary updates about their schedules from their supervisors.

h2.a: What resources are available for mental health supports during the COVID-19 outbreak?

div.p: The Tulsa Health Department has a helpline for Tulsans dealing with disaster-related emotional distress at 1-800-985-5990. We have also compiled a list of mental health resources that may be helpful for our families and employees.
Our Employee Assistance Program offers support, advice, and/or guidance to help you face the challenges that come your way.
Eligible employees and their family members are entitled to up to five confidential sessions with a counselor, financial planner, or attorney each calendar year.
For more information, visit Employee Assistance Program.

h2.a: Will teachers be allowed to work in classrooms for a few days before the students return? If we have to close the rest of the year, will teachers be able to close their rooms?

p.b: Our school buildings will NOT reopen this school year.

div.p: Teachers will not be able to enter the buildings at this time. However, all regular employees of Tulsa Public Schools, including teachers, administrators and support employees, shall be entitled to pay at their full contract rate for any work time lost when school buildings is closed and they are unable to work because of an epidemic.

We are prioritizing this to ensure we are supporting the well-being of our employees who are critical in ensuring we can provide quality instruction to our students. We are allowing our students, our staff, and our families the ability to socially distance themselves and slow the spread of COVID-19 in our community.

h2.a: Questions from Students

li.a: Will there be graduation ceremonies? What about athletics?
Will we have to make up time at the end of the year? We already have vacation, swim lessons, camps, etc. planned based on the original calendar.
How long will Tulsa Public Schools buildings be closed?
Can you elaborate on what you mean by distance learning? It sounds more like a list of links rather than a structured virtual learning plan.
Will I still be able to move on? Will I be able to graduate? Will they force us to make up this time with summer school?
Will I still have to take state tests? What about AP tests? We’re counting on those to help alleviate some college courses.
What resources are available for mental health supports during the COVID-19 outbreak?

h2.a: Will there be graduation ceremonies? What about athletics?

div.p: All scheduled performances, events, and other gatherings of more than 10 people that are postponed.

We are aware of the importance of school events for students, families, and the community. We are developing a comprehensive list of these events to prepare for postponements, cancellations, or changes in venue.

We are prioritizing this because we know that these are important experiences in the lives of our students and families. We will do what we can to provide these experiences in different ways while also keeping our students, staff and families safe.

While it is possible that we may be able to have graduation ceremonies this summer, our high school graduations will likely not be traditional ceremonies. However, our high school teachers and school leaders are committed to making sure that each senior earns their diploma and is able to celebrate that accomplishment.
We are partnering with our principals, teachers, coaches and team, OSSAA, and local partners as we continue to plan.

h2.a: Will we have to make up time at the end of the year? We already have vacation, swim lessons, camps, etc. planned based on the original calendar.

div.p: We are working with the Oklahoma State Department of Education regarding concerns around attendance, chronic absenteeism, course credits, and participation in state assessments.

We are prioritizing this because while our students deserve the opportunity to participate in college and career assessments, it is more important to prioritize the safety and well-being of students and Team Tulsa members. The Oklahoma State Department of Education is already working on scheduling a fall testing window for the SAT assessment for our current 11th graders.

h2.a: How long will Tulsa Public Schools buildings be closed?

div.p: The Oklahoma State Board of Education voted to approve State Superintendent Joy Hofmeister’s recommendation to implement a continuous learning plan without reopening school buildings. This means that while instruction of students resumed remotely on April 6, our school buildings will NOT reopen this school year.

Even as we face this unprecedented challenge, know that your child’s learning WILL continue this school year. Teaching and learning will look different over the next six weeks, but our teachers and school leaders will do all that they can to help students stay on track academically.
In the interim, know that:

ul.li: We will continue to provide breakfast and lunch meals to our students free of charge - you can find locations and times at www.tulsaschools.org/mealsites; and
We are providing activities and resources for at-home student engagement at www.tulsaschools.org/distancelearning, and printed materials are available at meal sites.

div.p: We will also continue to share information, updates, and resources on our website at www.tulsaschools.org.

h2.a: Can you elaborate on what you mean by distance learning? It sounds more like a list of links rather than a structured virtual learning plan.

div.p: Our school leaders and teachers will have plans in place to support student learning and engagement after April 6.

This is an unprecedented situation, and it is changing rapidly. We know that our team, students, and families have many questions. In particular, we know that our high school juniors and seniors are making post-secondary plans and need to understand what will happen next. Know that we hear your concerns and questions and that the district and your school will stay in close contact with you to address them. Please don’t hesitate to raise your concerns directly to your school’s leadership team as well.

We know that the uncertainty of this situation - especially when combined with this unprecedented experience - can be difficult and scary for all of us. Our commitment to you is to continue to share what we know for certain as soon as we know it, to answer your questions and address your concerns to the best of our ability, and to do all that we can to support everyone in our city as we make our way through this challenging time.

For more information and updates about our response to COVID-19, at-home engagement and enrichment activities for students, and meal services for children, visit our website at www.tulsaschools.org. We are updating our website multiple times a day to make sure you have the most up to date information, so please bookmark it and check back often.

h2.a: Will I still be able to move on? Will I be able to graduate? Will they force us to make up this time with summer school?

div.p: Even as we face this unprecedented challenge, know that your child’s learning WILL continue this school year. Teaching and learning will look different over the next six weeks, but our teachers and school leaders will do all that they can to help students stay on track academically.

We know that not all of our families have access to internet services and computers. We are working urgently with school leaders and their teams to understand what support and tools our families and teachers need in order to engage in remote learning. It is important to know that remote learning does not require that families have devices at home. While technology is an incredibly helpful tool, we are also working to accommodate the varied needs of the learners we serve.

h2.a: Will I still have to take state tests? What about AP tests? We’re counting on those to help alleviate some college courses.

div.p: We are working with the Oklahoma State Department of Education regarding concerns around attendance, chronic absenteeism, course credits, and participation in state assessments.

We are prioritizing this because while our students deserve the opportunity to participate in college and career assessments, it is more important to prioritize the safety and well-being of students and Team Tulsa members. The Oklahoma State Department of Education is already working on scheduling a fall testing window for the SAT assessment for our current 11th graders.

h2.a: What resources are available for mental health supports during the COVID-19 outbreak?

div.p: The Tulsa Health Department has a helpline for Tulsans dealing with disaster-related emotional distress at 1-800-985-5990. We have also compiled a list of mental health resources that may be helpful for our families and employees.
Our Employee Assistance Program offers support, advice, and/or guidance to help you face the challenges that come your way.
Eligible employees and their family members are entitled to up to five confidential sessions with a counselor, financial planner, or attorney each calendar year.
For more information, visit Employee Assistance Program.

h2.a: General Questions

li.a: WHAT DO I NEED TO KNOW ABOUT CORONAVIRUS?
WHAT CAN I DO TO PREVENT INFECTION?
What should I do if I have flu-like symptoms?
What are the CDC’s after-travel precautions?
WHERE CAN I FIND MORE INFORMATION?

h2.a: WHAT DO I NEED TO KNOW ABOUT CORONAVIRUS?

div.p: During recent months a new flu-like virus, called a novel coronavirus has originated in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China. This virus is a concern for public health globally because it is being transmitted from human to human and can cause serious illness including pneumonia, and in some cases can be fatal. The virus has spread, and the situation is evolving rapidly: the symptoms are similar to cold and influenza viruses and the infection is spread in the same way - no vaccination is available at this time.

h2.a: How is the coronavirus spread?

div.p: This virus originally emerged from an animal source but has been monitored spreading from person-to-person. Some viruses are highly contagious (like measles), while other viruses are less so. At this time, it’s unclear how easily or sustainably this virus is spreading between people. In general, coronaviruses spread through:

ul.li: Coughing or sneezing
Close personal contact, such as touching or shaking hands
Touching a surface with virus, then touching your mouth, nose or eyes before washing your hands

h2.a: WHAT CAN I DO TO PREVENT INFECTION?

p.b: You can prevent infection by doing the following:

ul.li: Wash your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds
Use alcohol-based sanitizers (60% alcohol or above) when hand-washing is unavailable
Help your young students to wash their hands well
Do not drop off your sick child at school and stay home when you are sick
Cover your nose and mouth when coughing and sneezing
Avoid close contact with anyone with cold or flu-like symptoms

h2.a: What should I do if I have flu-like symptoms?

p.strong: If you have cold or flu-like symptoms, you must:

ul.li: Follow local procedures: contact your doctor, as appropriate, and avoid close contact with others
Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when you cough or sneeze, then throw the tissue in the trash
Wash your hands often and thoroughly using soap and water and clean and sanitize objects and surfaces

h2.a: What are the CDC’s after-travel precautions?

div.p: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has issued the following after-travel health precautions for Level 2 and 3 countries only:

ul.li: Stay home for 14 days from the time you left the area and avoid contact with others.
Take your temperature with a thermometer two times a day and monitor for fever. Also watch for cough or trouble breathing.
Do not take public transportation, taxis, or ride-shares.
Avoid crowded places (such as shopping centers and movie theaters) and limit your activities in public.
Keep your distance from others (about six feet).

h2.a: WHERE CAN I FIND MORE INFORMATION?

div.p:
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: www.cdc.gov/coronavirus
Oklahoma State Department of Health: www.ok.gov/health
Tulsa Health Department: www.tulsa-health.org
